So if there was liquid in the can would it change what happens or take more or less power

I have to say, that looking at the Al can centered tightly in the coil, is the "perfect" situation for getting the strongest B-field positioned wrt the can...a few years back, I was wondering where the B-field produced by a solenoid is maximum. Some thought it may change with current. Most thought down the center axis, so I finally wrote a program (based on the Biot-Savart law) calculating this numerically. It turns out that the field is strongest:
1) inside the coil
2) as close to the INNER surface as you can get, ie, right at the inside wires, and
3) in the center of the coil
I even simulated current in the 'billions' of amps with tiny dl's...the program took days to run The field pattern does NOT change (just the field intensity).
Some MIT lectures even claim max. field is down the center axis!

I have had some luck with a re-usable quarter shrinking coil...one that does not explode!
ps
I've yet to zap a can...can't be better than seeing yours in slo-mo.

it was told that same magnetic feild lines repel
This i think is not true
Keep two magnets facing opp so that their field lines are opposite and what you see is that they repel
so Opposite field lines repel not parallel field lines

Hence the can produced opposite field lines not parallel field lines

The quarter was melted not squeezed by sending low voltage/high current through the flat surfaces of the ferrous pins. Similar to the way a Weller soldering gun works to heat the tip.While it is true electrons moving generate a magnetic field, the aluminum can is non ferrous and cannot be magnetized to create an electron cascade effect. Aluminum is conductive but electrons must be flowing through it and only while for it to attain magnetic properties. (This means you must apply a direct power/electron source to the can itself) No amount of magnetic field applied to it will induce a magnetic field and subsequent potential electrons or collection thereof. I call bull. Maybe the magnetic field has a similar effect as gravity has on all matter. We still don't understand the correlation between magnetism and gravity. Sparks/heat??? Does the field acting like gravity on non ferrous matter squeeze the can generating molecular friction thereby heat?
We see what we know...

next time you upload an educational video, please be more accurate, people are like information sponges, and being wrong has the price of misleading people to believe the wrong idea.
so:
- you should have mentioned in the graphics the direction of the induced current (why is it shown in a straight line? its not so abstract, you just have current running cylindrically)
- "the can has nowhere to go but inward" thats not true, as you can see how the cans fly outward.
the truth is that the current loops of the can feel the magnetic field of the coil, and is repelled outaward by it. this happens of both sides, so the can rips apart.
a simpler way to think about it, is that the can is like a solenoid-> a solenoid is like a magnet-> the can halves are like two magnets effected by the coil witch is a third magnet with the configuration of (SN-NS-SN) therefore repelled. it might not sound appealing in text, but quite easy in graphics.

The most interesting application is that when braking, high speed trains induce eddy currents into the rails, which creates a magnetic frictionless braking system. These trains also have the traditional brake pad on wheel system as backup and for lower speed stopping.  If these trains would have to rely on the traditional system at high speed, then it would be necessary to replace a lot of parts and overheating would always be a problem.  If a wheel overheats, it could disintegrate. The eddy current system does not brake using the wheels.

That was a lot of smoke coming off that quarter reaction. Whenever I see coated metal smoking, I get nervous because I have had to run from zinc clouds coming off burning galvanized metal. So seeing it in that quarter experiment made me wonder if there is anything in a quarter which could be toxic when arced.

According to wikipedia, the US Quarter is a copper nickel alloy, so it should be relatively safe (at least compared to galvanized metal) when arc burning. So I got nervous for nothing...but I did cause me to read about how a quarter is made, so I still got something useful out of it.

The explanation as to why aluminum induces a current the same direction as the enacted current is neglected.  Aluminum is diamagnetic, and thus works against any magnetic fields applied to it (over-simplified explanation).  This means that the aluminum is pushed away from the acting magnetic field, as opposed to a ferromagnetic substance, like iron, which would be attracted.  Saying aluminum is non-magnetic is basically calling this whole business magic.

Induced current sounds wrong. A voltage is induced, and if there is a complete path for current, current will flow. The Right Hand Rule for conductors works when talking about conventional current flow- or the relative motion of positive charge.

The 'magnetic' field is immaterial, in this example of a bilateral surface opposing rail gun,
the 'electric' field is the ticket. This rail gun simply fires the can in two directions at the
same time, elongating that center ring until the tensile strength is exceeded and the half
cans, as 'bullets', fire 'out' in the direction of the combined electromotive vectors. So, it
is that the aluminum can is 'conductive', not 'magnetically permeable'.

Diana I get that you're a science communicator but how does Joe justify being one? I mean isn't knowing science is an important part of communicating it? I have some qualms with your channel too mostly because of the over simplification. See while over simplification does make it interesting and fun it also takes away a lot of the substance and information that basically renders the topic just a mere curiosity like those Leiden Jars that was used to amuse people with electric discharges. But Faraday and Maxwell moved beyond the entertainment and they realized the importance of electromagnetism giving us what we see today. I believe simplifying science to such a level can only do more harm than good as Feynman said knowing the name of something is not knowing something. I hope you address this issue in the next episode, maybe less people will watch your "dumb show with tricky bits" but those who do will truly learn something rather than just getting some cheap entertainment. Thank you.

I'm really sad while watching your videos now. When I began watching your videos I really liked them and genuinely thought they were cool. Thanks to them I became incredibly interested in physics at school. But the one thing you don't show in your videos is the pain that is behind science. In this video I can hear only "this is awesome" and "this is so cool" which I don't say they are not but it's really not like the physics that is being taught at schools. The truth is that physics is not always this fun and exciting but there's a ton of complicated calculations, a lot of definitions behind it etc. I wish you showed more of this "boring" side of physics to people so that they can really see what it's all about.

I believe that at 3:00, the second magnetic field should be pointing in the opposite direction of the first magnetic field. This is because as the current in the electromagnet increases, this induces a current flowing in the opposite direction around the can, so as to try to keep the total magnetic field constant. The fact that the two currents are in opposite directions also explains why the two ends of the cans fly away from the electromagnet, rather than towards it.
